Post:
"I'm worried that my new therapist won't keep my secrets safe, and I'll end up feeling even more vulnerable." (SAS)

In this post, the individual attributes their concern about safety and privacy with their new therapist to their own vulnerability. They believe that they are naturally prone to being taken advantage of or harmed in some way, and this belief is reflected in their expectation that their therapist won't keep their secrets safe. This attribution style is stable because it implies that the individual sees themselves as inherently vulnerable, rather than recognizing that safety concerns are a normal part of seeking therapy.
Transferred_Post:
"I'm worried that my new therapist won't keep my secrets safe, and I'll end up feeling even more vulnerable." (UAS)

In this transferred post, the individual still expresses concern about their therapist keeping their secrets safe, but they attribute their worry to temporary factors such as the therapist's unfamiliarity with their case or a lack of trust in the therapeutic process. This attribution style is unstable because it implies that the individual recognizes that safety concerns are a normal part of seeking therapy and that they are not inherently vulnerable. By acknowledging that their worry is temporary and situational, the individual can address the root causes of their concern and work towards building trust with their therapist.
